data.title: ‘Drowsy Chaperone’ comes to CLU
data.meta_description: JAZZ AGE-STYLE MUSICAL—Malissa Marlow and Christopher Reynolds-Baldwin appear in CLU’s production of “The Drowsy Chaperone,” opening April 21 in the school’s black box theater. The Cal Lutheran University music and theater arts departments will present the Tony Award-winning musical “The Drowsy Chaperone” at 8 p.m. April 21, 22, 23, 24, 29 and 30 in the
data.text:
The Cal Lutheran University music and theater arts departments will present the Tony Award-winning musical “The Drowsy Chaperone” at 8 p.m. April 21, 22, 23, 24, 29 and 30 in the black box theater, 141 Memorial Pkwy., on the Thousand Oaks campus.

Matinees at 2 p.m. will be on Sat., April 23 and Sun., May 1.

“The Drowsy Chaperone” debuted on Broadway in 2006, winning five Tony Awards, including Best Original Score and Best Book of a Musical, and seven Drama Desk Awards.

The play is a send-up of the Jazz Age musical. As the houselights dim, a man in a chair appears on stage and puts on his favorite record: the cast recording of a fictitious 1928 musical. The recording comes to life as the man in the chair looks on.

The 20-member cast includes junior theater arts majors Leah Dalrymple of Simi Valley, Malissa Marlow of Thousand Oaks, Kevin Repich of Simi Valley and Chris Reynolds-Baldwin of Moreno Valley, as well as freshman Andrew Cervantes of Simi Valley.

Ken Gardner, chair of CLU’s theater arts department, directs. Music lecturer Heidi Valencia Vas provides musical direction, and music professor Daniel Geeting conducts the orchestra.

Barbara Wegher-Thompson, a senior adjunct faculty member in the theater arts department, is the choreographer.

Admission is $20.
